rowth components were calculated following the classical growth analysis method, in which changes in leaf area and biomass between two harvests are assumed to be exponential (Hunt, 1982). LNP was calculated as (loge(X2) _ loge(X1))/ (X2 _ X1) _ (Y1 _ Y2)/(t2 _ t1) where Xn is total leaf nitrogen, Yn is plant biomass and tn is time at the nth sampling.
trait.def: Leaf area ratio, leaf area:plant mass

RGR.eq: Harvested shoots (including branches) were oven dried at 95 C, and allometric relationships between shoot diameter and shoot dry mass (DM) were computed for each clone to estimate standing biomass at the plot level by scaling-up. For each clone, a potential yield (Mg DM ha_1 year_1) was computed over all plots and assessed years.

RGR.eq: rowth components were calculated following the classical growth analysis method, in which changes in leaf area and biomass between two harvests are assumed to be exponential (Hunt, 1982). LNP was calculated as (loge(X2) _ loge(X1))/ (X2 _ X1) _ (Y1 _ Y2)/(t2 _ t1) where Xn is total leaf nitrogen, Yn is plant biomass and tn is time at the nth sampling.
trait.def: leaf mass ratio leaf mass:plant mass

RGR.eq: RGR= (D2009-D2005/t); Relative growth rate (RGR) was expressed as the increment in stem diameter between March 2005 and March 2009, divided by the initial value of the stem diameter. Accumulative growth rate over the 4-year period was preferred instead of the average annual growth rate because of the high variability in growth during this initial stage in the life cycle of the plants.
